Humans have always tried to use various media to convey and general theme or message towards an audience. Whether that theme or message is true is irrelevant, but what is true is that humans definitely seek to reach a higher understanding with the art it creates. Incomes Gainax, blending stylistic origins to create a show that somehow defies a tradition that has persisted since the beginning of media itself. Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt doesn't try to reach for something higher. It contents itself with the cesspool that is basic entertainment and makes it tolerable, almost numbingly enlightening in the end. In the end, manywould call P&S a satire comedy, and I'm inclined to agree with them on most of the definition. However, unlike Kill la Kill, Trigger's attempt at satire, P&S doesn't become the very tropes it satirizes, and it strikes a healthy balance between the absurdity of the mundane and the comedy of the absurd.


Plot: 8/10

The story of P&S is neither episodic nor chronological, but rather something else entirely. While events of one episode may influence another, some episodes would be considered tragic endings in other shows. Deaths do not matter, as the show moves on with a sort of carefree leisure that is rarely seen of a story. It is as if the story satirizes all other stories with the way it moves so effortlessly forward, looking at possible plot holes with a snicker and walking away without patching it at all. While some would say that this is just bad script writing, the plot holes feel left open with purpose, not just because an overworked script writer said "Screw it" and smashed together a couple of plot devices to create a working story. The story is incoherent and random on purpose, and that gives most of the story a sense of freshness and exhilaration, allowing the viewer to focus solely on the art, the sound, and the badassery of the characters. Only at the end does the masterful styles of Gainax writing shine through, while at the same time laughing at themselves for repeating a very significant and memorable trope throughout their other shows. The story of P&S is nothing outstanding, only because it doesn't try to take center stage and let the other elements of the media shine through.


Art: 10/10

A beautiful weave of westernized influences and traditional anime styles, P&S combines two worlds that would've never met before, taking the best from both and making an art style that is uniquely Gainax and no one else's. From the animation of the opening to Panty and Stocking's transformations to the art style of episode 5, every moment feels planned out and detailed to perfection. The art in this show is definitely the strongest point, and may also be its most important point, as the wonderful palette and color combinations evoke a sense of brilliance and splendor like nothing else. Every moment is eye candy, and sometimes that is meant more literally than figuratively as we focus on the sweets that Stocking consumes. 


Sound: 9/10

Only slightly lacking behind art, the OST for P&S included the works of TeddyLoid, a wonderfully talented individual within the dance/electronica genre. Even now, Fly Away (Now) still rings in my ears as the beat pulses in the background of extremely auto-tuned vocals, almost a perversion of the normal human voice, but superbly catchy and beautiful in its own right. The opening and ending are among the best I've heard, with the opening taking a different approach by trying to imitate its western counterparts, opting for a shoutout of the titular characters backed by electronica rather than a true OP that most anime enjoy. The ending featuring Aimee B is one of innocence and bliss, almost like a palette cleanser after each beautifully vulgar episode.


Character: 8/10

Since P&S is a satire, it doesn't necessarily follow the rules of normal character progression either. Most of the characters stay generally the same throughout the series, with the main characters Panty and Stocking remaining static in their embodiment of lust and gluttony respectively. It is only at the end that Panty starts to change slightly and act differently towards Briefs, and it is only at the "ending" that Stocking shows anything else other than her undying affection for sweets. However static the characters might be, they are still extremely entertaining in their own right, as the characters are instead thrust into different plots and subplots instead of being stuck in a plot and forced to adapt episode after episode. Each episode is like a breath of fresh air with a little of the leftover dinner taste remaining, to remind you that the same old characters you loved are still here, and are still willing to kick anything's ass to get their way.


Overall: 8/10

Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt isn't your standard anime affair. It's like the bastard child of Adult Swim and Trigger, combining the best of both parents while also inheriting some of the worst. Watch P&S if you want a good laugh without having to worry about something of a higher echelon, if you want to throw yourself into a mind-boggling array of colors and electronic beats, if you want to enjoy everything the East and West has to offer without having to choose between them.

Let's play another game of "You Got It All Wrong," shall we? Well, firstly, this wasn't meant to be compared to other anime. Really, the show has a completely different spirit so shut up. Secondly, it's not a parody. It's more of a fusion of ideas, a loveletter to cartoons in general. This is the fusion of The Powerpuff Girls, Ran and Stimpy, also has the spirit of El Superbeasto and also includes some best parts of anime aside from its aesthetics while avoiding its many cliches. This fusion can also be seen in the OST which is eclectic and fully represents the spirit ofthis wild anime. Thirdly, the vulgar humor wasn't supposed to be funny EVERYTIME. They use the same method as El Superbeasto, throwing jokes rapidly until one of them hits and hits hard. This wasn't made because the authors are unfunny (the whole anime would suck otherwise) but more because the authors wanted to create that wild, over-the-top atmosphere that the show has. If a joke doesn't hit, it at least feels weird and doesn't annoy you like those cheap comedians on TV. Fourthly, the fanservice is not intrusive and wasn't supposed to grab your attention all the time. It is here because of the characters themselves. Just lay back and don't bother. You won't notice most of it because of the show's pacing. Maybe you'll even feel sad, heheh! Fifthly, the art style is not bad. In fact, it's extremely detailed and beautiful. It just has this PPG style which is completely alien to Gainax anime as much as Gainax style is completely alien to Western cartoons. It's awesome but not everyone will get its beauty. I completely don't get why. Sixthly, no, this Japanese cartoon doesn't suck because it doesn't have a consistent plot. Come on! It's about two wacky sisters going on adventures. This is a SatAM format. It's completely different. It's about watching bizarre, fun stories, not about going through a plot. And seventhly, you mustn't analyze it. This show is all about fun and adventures. So just relax, take it with an open heart. Don't listen to bad reviews. Don't listen to good reviews. You must FEEL this show. You must UNITE with this show. That means, you must experience it by yourself. You see, when you think it's a bad anime, you'll instantly drop it without giving it any chanse. When you think it's a good anime, you'll overhype it and think that it's the most hilarious thing ever yada-yada-yada and find things that aren't really there.\n
All in all, I think this is a great anime that is just unlike anything else, especially for a man who grew up not on Naruto or Eva but on SpongeBob, Kim Possible, Tom and Jerry and many many other gems. This is my favorite anime but it's probably because a have a soft spot for Western cartoons. I just love 'em and if I see that Japanese try to replicate their fun, wild, imaginative spirit just feels my heart with joy. My words to all haters: give it another chanse. Look at it from another angle. It's not just a bunch of juvenile jokes. It's more of an evolution of Western cartoons that touches the ground no other Western adult cartoon did (except Samurai Jack, of course. Good night, sweet prince). That is merging the fun and imagination of children cartoons with adult themes. Hope my review helped you make your decision whether watch this toon or not and maybe soften your opinion about this TV show.

Gurren Lagann and Kill la Kill are undeniably the most famous creations of Hiroyuki Imaishi, but the two of them are topped in terms of sheer batshit insanity by their oft-overlooked middle sibling, Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt.
Story
The story is very straightforward: two angels known as the Anarchy Sisters are kicked out of Heaven, and must fight their way back by killing Ghosts, supernatural creatures born from the regrets of the deceased. The older Anarchy Sister, Panty, is a blonde whore, who has the ambitious goal of having sex with 1000 men before returning to heaven, while the younger one, Stocking, is a blue andpink-haired goth with a massive sweet tooth. To combat Ghosts, they turn their lingerie into weapons; Panty turns her panties into a pistol, and Stocking turns her stockings into twin katanas. Other characters include Garterbelt, their mission control and stereotypical pedophile priest with a BDSM fetish; Brief, an unlucky high schooler in love with Panty; Chuck, a stuffed animal who exists solely to die; and their rivals, Scanty and Kneesocks, demons who seek to take over the city they reside in. 


The overall plot is much in the vein of 90's cartoons, in that each episode is made up of 2-3 skits, with little to no continuity in between. The premise itself is mostly an excuse for Panty and Stocking to do badass things, which is by no means a bad thing; the action scenes far outweigh the need for a deep story.


Art

The show from, an aesthetic standpoint is unique; nothing, from the characters to the background, looks like it belongs from an anime. Instead, the show takes cues from 90's cartoons, most notably The Powerpuff Girls. This unique artstyle is extremely satisfying to the eye, and goes hand-in-hand with some incredibly well-done fight scenes. There are some points in the series where the viewer can tell the animators used Flash, but the Western-inspired graphics don't make this a major problem.


Sound

While the artstyle is very appealing, the soundtrack is the crown jewel of the series. Every track is frenetic techno, devoted to finding their own perfect-fitting place in the show's fast-paced section. Some highlights include the Anarchy and Demon Sisters' respective themes, "Fly Away" and "I Want You", "Corset Theme", the leitmotif of the eponymous villain, and "Ghost Town", a track not heard in the series itself, instead only being released on an extra songs album.


Enjoyment

Here is where the show gets divisive. While the visuals and music are top-notch, the plot pieces are extremely offensives. Panty and Stocking, for lack of a better word, are not good people. They care only for their own interests, and they go through any means necessary to fulfill them. In every nook and cranny is a sexual innuendo, minus the innuendo part. Several beloved franchises, such as Barbie and Transformers, are bastardized to caricatures of themselves. Fortunately, the show is so offensive that, for some people, it becomes hilarious again. The show's episodic nature also adds to its rewatch value.


While the subbed version isn't half bad, the dub is what gives Panty & Stocking its own identity. Every sentence is filled with a cluster bomb of profanity, with snark added in for good measure. The voice actors themselves give it their all in playing their characters. Ever wanted to see Christopher Sabat play a black guy? look no further.


Cons

While the Demons' introduction episode is nothing short of amazing, they kind of bring the show down during its later half. No longer is the show about defeating ghosts, but dealing with their Team Rocket-esque shenanigans, which isn't as entertaining.


Additionally, while the series gives them equal billing, the story is clearly Panty's in the end, as Stocking is removed late in the series for the sake of Diabolus ex Machina.


While not that much of a serious con, the series's obligatory Gainax ending can leave a bad taste in one's mouth. Without spoiling too much, the show sets up the premise of a second season. However, it's left ambiguous whether or not it was supposed to happen, as Imaishi left Gainax months later to form Trigger. Regardless, the show has been stuck in limbo.


Conclusion

Overall, Panty & Stocking is insanity incarnate. It crosses every line in the book with an extremely crude blend of profanity and sexuality. It's clearly not for everyone, but if you're a fan of Hiroyuki Imaishi, then you'll find that his signature application of craziness, awesomeness, and fanservice shines though most in Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt.

Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt.  Just read the title.  It's not a deep or intellectually stimulating show.  It's mindless comedy and fun.  Thing is, that's just what I love sometimes.  I just let the immature side of me enjoy all the sexual jokes and swearing and I was not disappointed.  Anyways, onto the breakdown of my score.  PSG has somewhat of an overarching story, but it really flourishes with its episodic nature.  So the story is really weak, but still enjoyable, for me, anyway.  I give it a 7.  The art is fantastic.  Honestly,Gainax went ham on this and I love the way it looks.  The colors, the animation, and the cartoon-esque style are all so stimulating and beautiful to look at.  I have to give it a 10.  Speaking of 10s, Teddyloid did an amazing job with the OST for PSG, with its electronic feel.  It's addictive and fits the series overwhelmingly well.  The characters, while not very deep, are extremely fun to watch.  So, I give them a 9 as they are part of what makes PSG PSG, but lack very much development (except for Panty who gets a lot of the spotlight toward the end and the only development that could really be seen at all in the series).  I enjoyed this show a ton.  I turned my brain off and laughed so damn hard while watching it that it's one of the most enjoyable shows I've seen with the only bad episode I can remember being Chuck to the Future (seriously, what the hell was that?).  Grinding all of these scores together into the package known as PSG has me giving it a 9.  It's worth the watch and one of the most enjoyable comedy anime out there as long as you can enjoy the immature humor, references, and mindless fun.

Now that I got that out of the way, let's get down to bees knees!
What is this anime?
It's an unapologetic, super stylistic, super lewd, but super good anime rife with pop culture references that sticks to its essence from start to end.(I did this for the rhymes, bruh!)
What is that essence?
Absurdity!
The premise itself is quite simple. Two disgraced angels forced to "community service" in a city of sinners so that they can get back to heaven. But what was born out of thatsimplicity is something I haven't seen before.


If you decided to watch it you'll embark on a quest with two fallen angels in a city of sinners in an absurd journey filled with hilarious characters, ludicrous situations , a couple of gratuitous moe-ments, an array of lewd subjects, and satirical depictions ranging from other media to sexual things told through a super stylistic art and dynamic scenes that makes the action sequences pop. *draws breath


And yet with its heavy load(tehehehe) of lewd materials, the show successfully managed not to break the hymen of hentai and delivered an orgasmic experience anyway.


Also the music really fits the whole thing, which is always good.


This show is what it is. It's completely honest with itself and doesn't try to be more than what it is; a light, lewd, fun, comedy anime full of absurd things. That is why I think this anime is wonderful, because it's different and it's proud of it's uniqueness.



Is it for everyone?


Heeeelll No!!


Should you watch it when your family members are around without earphones on?


Heeeelll No!!


Is it good?


Heeeelll Yes!!

In my opinion the English Dub is better than the Sub.
The soundtracks in this anime is one of the best I've heard aswell. Anyways, for those who are debating on whether or not to watch PASWG, beware of the ending 'cause OH BOI! it actually pissed me off.

I watched enough anime to know were this is going - actually, no I don't.
Panty and Stocking drop a bunch of vulgar humor throughout the anime, but that's not their only job. They are angels who use their clothing to fend off evil beings.
I thought this anime would have a feminism kind of feel, it didn't take many episodes to prove me wrong. Panty and Stocking say, do, and be whatever they want without giving a crap about what anyone says.
The art style reminds me of... Dead Leaves and Afro Samurai. There is also a Dexter Laboratory/Power Puff girls feel in the artwork (but that'sjust me). One thing I did notice is that Gainax wasn't that smart with censorship at some scenes. There were some scenes with a beam of light magically popped out and it was just a little frustrating trying to figure out what was going on. There were other times when they played the censorship card in a smart way (I wont explain just watch). The only two characters I'll mention are of course, Panty and Stocking. Panty is quite the interesting character she enjoys sex and her clothing turns into a gun. Unlike Stocking, she enjoys external pleasure. Stocking however, enjoys alone time eating sweets as she scolds her sister's actions throughout most of the show.\n\n
It is hard to decide the underlying message(s) of this show. If there is one I would mention it's that your first time with your partner should be a special moment (It's hard to pick up but watch the anime with a keen eye and clear mind).\n\n
If you like vulgar humor, girls that use clothing to fend off evil, and\n
unique art style to an anime then this anime is for you. However, you'll be disappointed if you're expecting a deep story.

Panty and Stocking: With Garter-Belt (or PSG for short) is quite possibly the worse anime of all time, and I’ll explain why. 
Seemingly in accordance with Gainax tradition, PSG contains many deep themes of religion, sin, and the struggle between morality and evil. However, it lacks angelic mechs and forehead-limbs. And unlike another religion-themed Gainax title, this show is disappointingly shallow and paralyzingly uncreative. It is pretty much the Japanese equivalent of South Park. (indeed, one segment of the show is done in a “South Park” animation style) With sex-jokes, racism, swearing, and more fan-service and innuendo than some hentai titles all throughout the show,PSG is as unmodest as it is bad. 


In my opinion, PSG had potential, lots of it, but the way PSG's creators put (or rather, threw) things togeather fail horribly. I forget where I read it, but I once saw something that claimed PSG’s creators were often drunk or getting drunk during the show’s production. Now, I don’t know if this is true or not, and I kind of doubt they were intoxicated ALL the time, but after watching a few episodes of PSG on the internet, I could see the creators being under the influence of some kind of drug at one point during this show’s creation. And really I only watched one episode. That was all I could muster. Anything else and I think my face would have exploded after turned redder than Scanty's skin. 


I have to give one thing to Panty and Stocking: it has quite an awesome Original Sound-Track (OST), which consists mainly of techno and dance music, as well as some pop-rockish stuff. The songs play at various points throughout the show to increase the impact of the scene. PSG's sound-track it one of its few redeeming features.


Another thing that I gleaned from this show was probably the only truly thought-provoking theme of the show, and that is the division between East and West. 


Traditional Japanese animation won’t be found in this show, because PSG looks something like a combination of two American cartoons: Invader Zim and The Power-Puff Girls. This is the struggle between Eastern animation and Western animation. Panty, a bona-fide WASP in a red dress and high-heels loves sex and has the dirtiest mouth this side of the Pacific Ocean. Plus she is proud of it and doesn't hide this fact. If anything, she goes out of her way to let people know just how raunchy she is. 


Panty is a stereotype of the West, while the relatively quiet and much more modest Stocking represents the East. Stocking's gothic/lolita attire is also a theme of East-Asian, or more specifically, Japanese culture, as such garb is popular among cosplayers of all sorts.


In that regard, Hiroyuki Imaishi, the "creator" of Panty and Stocking had a Panty-like character in his 2002 Title, “Magical Shopping Arcade Abenobashi.” The American, as this guy is called, is a blatant stereotype of Americans. This guy is on screen for less than a minute, but he’s by far my favorite character in the show. Due to his brand of humor being jam-packed into >60 seconds, it is so much funnier than the humor of PSG, which overdoes its crude humor by shoving it down your throat every single damn episode. Panty is funny for about a minute, then becomes overplayed, drawn-out, and forced.


The f**king American was a lot f**king funnier. F**k yeah! 


Overall, Panty and Stocking with Garter-Belt has more cons than pros. It’s few redeeming features are ok in their own regard, but them being stuck in a crap show like this hinders their impact. Only watch this show if you don't mind losing a few I.Q. points, or your virginity for that matter. 


/end gigantic wall of text review.

I thought this anime was very fun, positive, and a wonderful thing to watch to lift your spirits after an eight hour shift at work.
The storyline reminded me of a typical American cartoon that I would watch as a child. In general, two fifteen minute novella like episodes tied into one thirty minute actual episode. It was a nice setup, and I found that if I walked away for a second to grab a drink, or answer a phone call, I wouldn't be completely lost and wondering what was going on. Each episode held its own. The relationship between two sisters, angels even, was nothingnear heavenly and I appreciated that the creators made the sisters fight, make up, toss insults, and back each other up. Every time they fought together against the Ghosts, I nearly giggled with delight. And that each Ghost was downright silly was even better. Nothing too serious here. The vomit episode, anyone?


The art and sound were amazing. I enjoyed the varying designs and styles of drawing found in each episode, as well as the blowing-up animation of defeated Ghosts. The transitioning from each style was fairly smooth, and it added to the overall appearance of the show. The transformation song of Panty and Stocking reminded me of something I had heard on the radio long ago.


Each character had their own unique story, background, style of dress, and even skin color - ranging from completely normal to abnormal and questionable. I loved it. Panty was a fun-loving slut, Stocking loved sweets, and so on and so forth. The fact that there was a black character, as a main character even, made me very happy. I found that I could relate to each character, at least a little, and grew to love Scanty and Stocking as my favorites. 


I enjoyed this. It was a walk in the park compared to all of the other dramatic, feels-inducing anime I've seen lately. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a break from serious life, or just someone looking for some more mature humor without having to be committed to a drawn out storyline.

Right off the bat: this is a very polarizing series. People generally tend to think P&S is either zany and hilarious with a crude but palatable sense of humor, or an incomprehensible jumble of bright colors and jokes written for the lowest of brows. As evidenced by my ratings, I fall into the first category. 
To rate the art style of the series feels a bit insufficient, as there exist at least three separate art styles. The first of which is the Powerpuff Girls-esque style in which most of the series is done an in which body proportions are a bit skewed, another more "realistic"style used primarily in the transformation scenes, one which was used exclusively in one episode that reminiscent of "indie surrealist anime" (for lack of a better description), and live action (mostly models of ghosts being destroyed). The switch between the visual styles underscores how light hearted and completely not serious the series is, and can almost be seen as a treat. 


The soundtrack is amazing, but given that this is a Gainax work, that shouldn't be surprising. Of the more notable musical entries are the transformation scenes with their bass-heavy strip-club air about them, the ending song that is light and much more tame than the rest of the series, and even a slow love song that Stocking delivers. 


The characters are certainly colorful, even if they lack depth. The main cast consists of a nymphomaniac with anger issues, a goth with a sweet tooth, a priest with an absurd hairstyle and a share of fetishes, an introverted "geek" who allows himself to be strung around by the aforementioned nymphomaniac, and  a mascot character that looks suspiciously like Gir from Invader Zim. Speaking of Invader Zim, references in this series abound from Transformers (an episode that doubled as the Gainax contractual requirement for mecha in a series), Fight Club, Back to the Future, and even Ren and Stimpy.


If I had to relay any major critiques of the series, it's that P&S refused to end properly. Without wishing to spoil anything, the final 3 minutes of the last episode set up another arc and a major plot twist with no intention of actually delving into it (well, perhaps there will be a second season). 


In summary, Panty and Stocking with Garderbelt is a series that is best enjoyed for the spectacle that it is. It's not particularly deep and it may be immature, but that's all part of the charm of the series. If nothing else, you won't see anything else like it and should at least give it a shot.

Back when Gainax produced Neon Genesis Evangelion and changed mecha anime history forever, they say the artists were so tired of the gloomy mood they got while working at that (I can feel for them), they decided to went for something fast, funny, and random as hell for their next series. Now Gainax produced Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann, changing mecha anime history forever AGAIN, and even though that's certainly not gloomy, and these series were not produced back-to-back, I suppose it was time for yet another bit of fast, funny, and RANDOM AS ALL OF HELL anime from our favourite trolls. Enter Panty & Stocking(with Garterbelt).


This show, you'll get it by reading all other reviews, is a polarizing one. On a first layer, it's a funny bit of potty comedy that will have you laughing in a very silly way. Watch it from the point of view of someone who feels too adult and mature for this stuff and looks for depth and profound messages (or ecchi moe girls) in anime, and it'll feel like a bunch of bad, unfunny jokes stuck together. But watch it being someone who already went and saw most of what anime has to offer and is getting tired of its clichés, and be willing to go beyond the obvious, and you'll find out that it's a series brimming with originality, audacious in giving the middle finger and trolling the hell out of the viewers' expectations and of the rest of the anime industry, fast, well made, chockfull of parodies and cultural references, and ultimately with a powerful moral/political statement to be made (but not in an exceedingly serious way). Oh, and it's got a lot of excellent potty comedy too.


The plot is easily laid down: we got two angel sisters, Panty and Stocking, who instead of being the epitomes of purity are a little on the sinful side. They've been kicked out of Heaven (one has to admit their vices make them not very effective at their jobs) and have to earn their way back in by killing evil spirits. In this task they are assisted by a priest of dubious morals known as Garterbelt and a weird pet who takes on the role of the resident Kenny (that is, he gets inconsequentially killed every now and then), and who they tell me looks like someone from something called "Invader Zim". I wouldn't know, never watched that show. But I digress.


Panty and Stocking will fight Ghosts and Demons using the eponymous pieces of underwear as weapons. They will confront spirits who are the manifestation of things like poop, snot, and sperm. They will eat sweets. They will fight between themselves.  They will have sex (not between themselves. Yeah, sorry, guys, I know I just killed your hopes). They will just slack off, sometimes. And in all of this they will manage to look much more real characters than you'd usually get in anime - because they act like real people,  if maybe with some comedic exaggeration, not amorphous, fantasy-fulfilling moeblobs. You want to fap to the 2D image of a pure, chaste girl who will depend entirely on you and do whatever you want her to? "Screw you," says Gainax "here you get a heroine who can kick your butt multiple times around the Earth and will only care about the size of your junk to decide whether she cares about you or not. Deal with it." At which point, the writers put on their sunglasses and drive into the sunset with the sport cars they bought with the income of the mass sellings of alluring Rei Ayanami figurines to ronery otakus, while the "Trolololo" song plays in the background.


I think this show is genius. It is for the creativity of very episode: they are all different, even in art style sometimes, and the more different they are, the more I liked them! It is for the very premise and concept. It is for the simple idea that Heaven and Hell represent Order and Chaos... only with Heaven being actually the Chaos side. It is because it's an enormous statement about freedom from social judgement, and boy, do we need some of that! It is because of the ending... no, wait. F**k the ending. Not that. Damn you Gainax. You trolled me again. 


Still better than End of Evangelion though.


But yeah. Not gonna spoil, but it's a bit of a mindscrew (which kind of makes sense since at that point in the series we already got ALL OTHER KINDS OF SCREW HUMANLY CONCEIVABLE). Doesn't ruin the series though, also because of its episodic nature which never really develops a full-fledged plot.


Also, the art is excellent - american style but incredibly detailed and fluid - and the music is friggin' amazing. Obligatory technical note.


Well, if you read my review and thought it raised your interest, go watching P&S nau. If you thought that I was just trying to rationalize and justify with grand words a bunch of potty humour, or worse, if you thought that you don't want to watch a show whose main protagonist is a "slut" (don't listen to them, Panty, I love you! Wait, why is there an used condom on your bedside table...?), well, if you thought that, then you'll probably be better off not watching it. All the rest of you, have fun with the most unique anime series of all time.

From the very first minutes of this story you will either be sucked in by its more inappropriate sexual innuendo than a kids bop album antics or forced to run very far far away. I like the characters from the start there crazy new and kind of unique to the more traditional characters we see. and the four main characters jive well enough.
The story like most others is predictable but its quick paced action, and sexual misdirections keep you from seeing alot of the things that this anime fail at. But getting away from the critical synopsis if you walking into a show withcharacters named Panty, Stocking and Garterbelt and expect Shakespeare than you really need to adjust your viewing habits. \n\n
If you like potty humor and attractive females that drop into action sequences with guns blaring this is you, if not run run far far away.  Think excel saga meets powerpuff girls vs 1 night in paris and your right about where this anime starts off. Enjoy!

Ladies and Gentlemen let me give you the 411  on one of my favorite anime's. . . . Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt. 
Now coming from a women's prospective I find this anime to be orgasmic, why? Well it's simple, because panties and stockings are used as weapons I mean come on, can it get any better then that? 
Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt is a must see you will probably pee your pants from laughing so much and most likely get sexually aroused depending on how perverted you are. It's the perfect combination of comedy and flat out  pervertedness. Its basically acouple of explicit  sex/tentacle scenes away form being a hentai.


Lets get serious though, Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt reminded me of a grown up version of the Powerpuff Girls. I absolutely loved every second of it. The story mostly revolves around the Anarchy sisters Panty and Stocking. 


-Anarchy Panty, the older of the two, is a loud mouthed sex addicted angel. She has low standards in men and is usually unsatisfied after its all said and done. Panty, unlike Stocking, doesn't take her job as a ghost-hunter seriously, she mainly focuses on fulfilling her personal goal of sleeping with one thousand men during her stay on Earth. Panty is able to weaponize not only panties but boxers and briefs into guns. However the power of the weapon for male underwear depends on well. . .you'll figure it out. 


-Anarchy Stocking on the other hand, is a some what rude but level-headed and intelligent girl. Stocking enjoys indulging herself in various desserts and sugary food while still managing to stay skinny (she assures all the fat goes towards her breasts). Stocking can weaponize stockings into katanas and she has quite the bondage fetish.


They were banished from Heaven due to their bad behavior and sent to Daten City, a place located on the edge of Heaven and Earth where their supposed to spend their days hunting down and killing the Ghosts while also collecting Heaven Coins so they can buy their way back into Heaven.



Over all, I loved all the characters and the story line although I have to admit I was a little confused at times (plus the art wasn't exactly the best). I definitely enjoyed the OST and I absolutely adored the voice acting in English and Japanese, well done.



I would definitely recommend this anime to anyone 18+ or maybe 14+ if you're mature. I only wish there was a  second season, episode 13 was a horrible cliff hanger.

Definitely not suitable meant for children, though many of the sex jokes are subtly told.  Quite the wacky show. 
Despite its randomness and little plot, the show keeps up a good pace and stimulates enjoyment (for the most part). Despite its "power-puff girl"-like art, the authentic characters and wacky visuals give this show its own charm that makes it memorable. 
There is something there about this anime that (like not many other anime) makes this anime find its own special place in my heart. Perhaps it is due to its uniqueness and how it is well portrayed.
The best part of the show is the(main) characters. \n\n
Note: I actually watched almost the whole thing Dubbed and the American voice actors were great!

Wow, I ehhhh, don't know where to even begin with this.    This show is one of the best shows I've seen yet worse ones at the same time.    So much to like yet so much to hate.
Story:    The story of Panty & Stocking with Garterbelt is basically about two Angels named Panty and Stocking who go around and destroy ghosts in order to gain Heaven Coins.  Through out the series, the various events happen and the over arcing story is kind of lost but thats fine.    Also, the weapons that the maintwo use are Panty using her panty as a gun, and Stocking using her stockings as a blade.   How silly is that lol.   Aside from that, there is not much else to say about the story itself.




Art:    This is one where some will like it or hate it.   The art style is unique to anime IMO, but the art style is very similar to some old cartoons I watched as a kid on cartoonnetwork. There are certain parts where the art takes on a more realistic form and the characters look very nice.    The setting of the show has a very whimsical sort of feel and things have very sharp edges and curvy points.    





Sound:    The music is what kept me going because of how catchy and funky it was.  Just listen to Fly Away from the OST or watch half of the first episode and you will hear it when Panty and Stocking are transforming.    If you like electronic type of style and tracks with good downbeats,then you should like the music here.    Also, there are many songs that are used from other films like Rocky and Space Odyssey 2001 or are very slightly altered to avoid copyright issues.    Strong point for the series.




Characters:   This is another part that will make or break the show for people.  The main two characters are basically very very sleazy girls who bang a ton of guys, especially Panty since Stocking has a slight bit better sense of taste and is not as open as Panty is.   They also swear a LOT, and I mean a LOT, and not just things like shit or damn, but like flat out, f bombs and other very suggestive things as well.   To me, it was over the top and got stale, but at times, it was right on and funny.   Still, its not common to hear that sort of language too often.




Enjoyment:    Personally, I kept watching because of the music, the lewd jokes that I could partially relate to, and the outrageousness of the whole show.  There are times where it was annoying and I would skip a bit just to get past an annoying scene or two, but outside of that, it was funny from beginning to the end. 




Overall:   If you can handle the very strong coarse language and the overwhelming amount of penis and sex jokes in general, then you should give this a shot.   If anything, watch the first episode and wait til the transformation scene.     And since I rarely rarely consider watching the dub for shows, Ill also add that the dub version of this show, is very well done.    Language seems to be even more over the top, but the voice actors nailed the roles pretty well, even the small characters.

Panty & Stocking is an interesting anime. I found out about it from a GIF of Stocking eating pudding and everyone in a forum raging about it. It looked cool enough and was apparently amazing so I tried it out. This anime is not amazing. I found myself bored more then half the time. It only got better near the end then the ending sort of disappointed me. Here is why.
The plot is simple. Two fallen angels are given the chance to go back to Heaven by collecting Heaven Coins. These Heaven Coins are retrieved from defeating ghosts that walk the surface. That's pretty muchit. It's one of them monster of the week things going on except more cool. I will not deny it's coolness coz this show is cool. Just not cool enough.


So the story is shallow and you get really don't anything until the end. However the end plot was kind of WTF?? and didn't make much sense to me. Well it did in the end but you know. Some of the mini plots were cute, some were funny, some were hilarious and some were just boring. It's mainly the two angels just indulging themselves. Story was definitely the weakest point.


The art was awesome. It was like eye candy!! Soo pretty and everything even though it is comparable to the art style of the Powerpuff Girls. Most of the animation screamed western style with a touch of eastern style. Even so, it was pretty cool. I thought it was beautiful and a nice change from what your typical anime looks like. 


Sound was even better then the art. Every song was sooo catchy. I LOVE the ending soo much. The OP reminded me of those cartoons you'd watch as a little kid and sing along with cept this time I sang in my head. The transformation theme songs were cool. I liked it..quite a bit :)


The voice acting was fine to me. Stocking sounded so cute and Panty sounds just like a stuck up whore. Mind you, she does have her kind moments. I'm not dissing Panty. I like her as much as Stocking. I'm just saying. Brief had an annoying voice which sort of suited his character. So yeah, sound is all good.


Hmmm..characters. The characters are shallow. I didn't like them that much even though I found them pretty awesome. Pretty contradictory huh? I think that's just the show. Some bits are awesome, some bits are terrible. Anyways, I would say, one of the best characters would be Chuck. I loved Chuck. At first I found him annoying but I grew to think he was better. Stocking was pretty cool as well. The characters don't have much of a back story. You do get a bit of a back story during the 2nd or 3rd last episodes. No-one's really explained properly and I'm still iffy on a few things.


I got bored. A lot to be honest. I watched through pretty much every episode wondering 'when is it ever gonna become awesome?'. That never really happened. Like I said before, some episodes were great but most were meh. There's a bit of fanservice in here but that doesn't appeal to me. 


I believe that this series depended on its 'awesomeness' to get the viewers. It doesn't go into any big details. TTGL was sort of the same (both are made by Gainax) so in a way, I guess I'm not really surprised. I was disappointed in this series. I went in with high expectations and didn't get that much out of it. I guess, if you're gonna watch it, don't do what I did and go in with high expectations. I don't think you can make a good anime based on how 'awesome' it is. Panty & Stocking as not good but it was somewhat entertaining. Just go in with a shallow mind and you should be fine :)

Welp, this is a really hard anime to review as much of it is really dark humor and parodies. It’s sort of like trying to review ‘South Park’ in that way. People will love it or hate it. I actually might be a mix though of both liking it and hating it strangely enough. It’s not that I really like that type of crude humor that they do, its just… for some reason I actually like the main characters and how simple they are. I know that is odd for me to say, but this one is one of those anime that is probably bestwatched without thinking to much. For example, their first episode has people being sucked down toilets and the main characters have to fight a large poop monster. It’s just something better left without thinking to much on it. 


The characters are really simple to talk about as each character is pretty one personality. The first character is Panty. Yes, her name is the same name as the garment that woman wear, and pretty much the aspect that defines her the most. She is a slut to put mildly, sleeping with every man she can get her hands on. Well almost anyone, there is like two male characters she doesn’t touch throughout the show but other then that she has probably slept with them. She just seems to not be able to get enough of it. Her weapon of choice is her Panty/gun named Blacklace which seems to end up in every color but actually black. 


The next character would be Stocking, Panty’s gothic sister. Her main gimmick is being really into sugar treats. I mean really into them to where she will consume a large amount in one sitting. Other then that, the only time she seems to have sexual urges like her sister is when it has something to do with BnS based like being tied up. Where Panty dresses as a high class party girl, Stocking is more into the darker Lolita fashion. Her weapons of choice are her stockings/Katanas Stripe I and Stripe II. 


Brief is basically a geeky ghost hunter type guy who seemed to end up following the girls around and ‘trying’ to help them as they fight the ghosts and demons of that world. He is actually a bit more complex of a character then the other two girls but most of that comes later on in the episodes. Basically the only reason why I think he actually seems to follow the girls around is that he has feelings for Panty though she never looks his direction. I thought of him as the most innocent of any of the characters.


We also have Garterbelt, the Anarchy sister’s guardian and a reverend of the church they live in. He… he makes me really uncomfortable. His characteristics are based off of ‘Black Dynamite’ I think as he has a large black afro and has dark skin as well as a incredible deep powerful voice. He um… he likes little boys with his eyes sort of set on Brief for some reason and also seems to have a hobby in being a dominatrix. Ya… he scares me.


So for this next character, I have to bring up ‘Invader Zim’. You remember the little robot named Gir from that show and the dog outfit he would wear. Well, Chuck is pretty much him in this show. He is goofy, a punching bag, and pretty much something to abuse in the show. That’s just his character it seems. Why he doesn’t just end up running off is beyond me.


This show is really heavy handed on the Parody part of their comedy, especially in the English Version. If you watch any version at all, I would suggest the English one, partly because of the voice actors and partly because the comedy seems to get lost in the Japanese if you don’t know all of there parody stuff. They did take things from both areas, both the east and west but without having the English version of the parody, I didn’t really get it myself. Sometimes the parody is easy to figure out, and sometimes it’s really hidden.


The artwork is really jagged and got a style similar to a lot of the stuff we been seeing here in America lately. I don’t really think I saw any character that actually had a rounded shape except for the large afro that Garterbelt has. In fact, everything seems to change shape, style, and sometimes personality depending on the parody they were trying to go for. We can go from a crazy card board cut out look to a black and white episode with normal anime style thrown in for the strip tease transformations that they do. Ya, the transformation into an angel is pretty much them poll dancing.


I love the English voice actors and sound track. Again, this seems to be like Hetalia in that both Japanese and English are good though it’s much easier to get the jokes if you’re watching your native language. I have to say, hearing Vic Mignogna as the boogie ghost Oscar H. Genius is pretty funny as well as hearing both Jamie Marchi and Monica Rial curse every few seconds. I kid you not, they did a awesome job with that and when she first started talking, I was just staring at my screen in shock. Here is a little known fact for those who do not know a lot of voice actors. The voice actor for Garterbelt is Christopher Sabat, and surprisingly he is not black. That might sound racist, but I’m not trying to be. The character seriously sounds like a black man the way they portrayed him and I give Christopher props for being able to pull that off. The opening music is pretty fun with an upbeat sort of rap song though its way to short and just has the person saying the characters names over and over again. The ending song is where my love of the music is. The song is called ‘Fallen Angel’ and I just fell in love with the soft sad lyrics. I also have a little bit of a love for the transformation song that they use too.


By the way, the ending pretty much throws the whole show into a 180 and actually has a really awesome story at the end. Warning, watch all the way to the end of the last episode and after the credits, there is something special that you may miss if you don’t! It hints of a new season to come (Although I haven’t heard anything about another one coming out).

Fuck it, LET'S ROLL!
STORY: "Continuity? Who gives a fuck?!"
Panty & Stocking w/ Garterbelt or PSG as I would like to call it in the duration of this review, is a show not meant to be taken seriously from the get-go. You can probably already guess it from the title itself. Anyway, to the story - it's pure menace. To sum it all up, it's pretty erotic and gross at the same time. The producers went all out putting into manifestation all the crazies they can come up with, joking about sex and shit, literally. But it all works fine; the result is downright comedy whetheryou laugh it from the Anarchy Sisters' bitchiness or the Western culture references that pop-up once in a while. Scratch that - this show is a pure lashback at everything Western. But perhaps I am still looking for a decent story in this show and by taking a step back and looking at the bigger picture, I can say that its probably the weakest part of the PSG, but don't let that get you a bad impression of what PSG tells; overall, it's funny, it's dark, quite gross and entertaining to watch if you don't mind sheer amount of vulgarity and sex references.


Watch out for that ending though. Obligatory for a Gainax ending, you'll be mind fucked.


CHARACTERS: "Angel bitches are fun."

Probably the biggest driving force of the show's comedy and story are its characters. I love Panty's sex-hungry persona and Stocking's somewhat down-to-earth mentality. Either way, these girls are wild, overbearing and entertaining to watch when they blow-up stuff and argue amongst themselves. 


Other characters are notable as well; Garterbelt is a black-afro priest who I like for being the straight-man within the girls misadventures. The two demon sisters for being cunning but constantly failing in their plots. Brief was a great male lead and so much so especially in the last episodes. And the bad guy (no, not the ghosts) who I barely give a fuck about until he showed up...


AESTHETICS & AUDIO: "Holy hell, it's Powerpuff Girls in crack and aphrodisiac!"

The one thing that makes PSG distinguishable from the moe-blobs of today is its visual style, and holy shit it's tasteful and simply remarkable. If you've watched a lot of Cartoon Network as a kid, you can probably point out where Gainax took their inspiration from, but then slapped it with all the nitty-gritty of hentai and super sentai explosions. It's not the best visual style of anime I've seen out there, but it's downright memorable and rightfully so. 


The same can be said for the soundtrack. I'm not much of a sound guy but all the music and noises in the show are great and a treat to hear. The songs aren't obviously sung in "Engrish" fortunately since they're not awkward to listen to.


As for voice acting, I'll just say right off the bat that I'm glad to watch PSG first in full-dub, because if it wasn't I would be able to grasp the overall tone of the show. The voice actors of each respective language did great giving voice and personality to their characters but I just have to applaud the dub for having an awesome set of voice actors and the rich script. You can hate me all you want for saying this, but for an anime like this, it's better suited to watch it in English since, in my opinion, feels natural considering the visual style. 


VERDICT: "Fuckin' A!"

Panty & Stocking w/ Garterbelt sticks out like a sore thumb from all the anime I've watched thus far, and for good reasons. The wacky story, zany characters, and unconventional visual style makes PSG a must watch. Things to consider though are the vulgarity, over-the-top antics, unserious story and even the overall look. The appeal of PSG may not apply to all. but in my experience it was one hell of a show. Now, if they'd delivered in there promise of giving us a second season, I'd go all out for this show. C'mon Gainax!

Panty: Being a bitch is about living freely. Nothing holds a bitch down - nothing can. 
After my first viewing of Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt - which was during my high school years - my impression was: it looks like a show that I'd watch during a 1990's/early 2000's Cartoon Network Block but feels like a show I'd watch during late night block of Comedy Central or Adult Swim. Due to that impression, I tended to devalue everything about the show. Panty and Stocking were two simple minded characters interested in nothing but sex and sweets respectively. Garterbelt taken fused from the blaxploitation filmsof the 1970s and the head honcho of Charlie's Angels slathered with sexual fetishes that I'm not talking about. And Chuck the punching bag. I'm writing this review because I had to reassess my thoughts on this show after a second viewing. Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt comes off as style over substance but that style is grounded with a very simple but effective thematic foundation. Naysayers, I ask you, what are Panty and Stockings last names...Anarchy. Break anarchy into its root words - a(n): not, without / arch: first, to rule - and you get without rulers. Now what does that imply within context of the show. Doing what every the fuck you want without fear of the consequences from preconceived notions/symbols/figures of authority. This point cemented in my mind when a pair of antagonists ask (I'm paraphrasing) if they have any rules or codes of conduct they follow, Panty replies: "You idiot. 'Rules' exist to be broken" This quote sums up what this show strives for and successfully obtains. 



The preconceived notion is that Panty, Stocking, and other recurring characters are one note characters that lack depth; I disagree for two reasons. The first reason, Panty and Stocking are static characters; meaning that they will have the same personality from start to finish. And outside of certain regressions and reconstructions, the duo you see is what you get and that's not a bad thing. Because their ideology of anarchy is the catalyst for other character's growth. The easiest example I have to back up this claim are the daemon sisters, Scanty and Kneesocks. When first introduced, they are the anarchy sister's polar opposites with their strict self-discipline, a code of conduct, and polite public personas. But after their first battle we start to see them absorb a bit from Panty and Stocking's ideology and set traps, frame, cheat, and generally ignore the rules they held in high standard, all in an attempt to achieve their goals. They fail of course but I thought it was interesting that the protagonists forced the antagonists to grow. You see smaller but similar developments in Brief, Chuck, and Gaterbelt around the time of the final episodes. If it wasn't for the Anarchy sisters the others wouldn't grow and the show would amount to what many people already criticize it for boring/pointless.


The second reason: we observe static personalities in extreme situations which allows us to see glimpses of hidden depths. After the routine the show has lulled us into we see Panty and Stocking, two badass angels who don't break a sweat when it comes to physical combat, fall into vulnerable positions that challenge them on a individual level and their place in the world. The particular challenge that Stocking faces deals with love and we see what she's willing to sacrifice in order to pursue it; which might surprise you since the show does portrayed her in a self-absorbed, selfish, hedonistic light. Panty goes through her own struggle and we even see a small glimpse of how she'd act if her personality did a complete 360. I argue that these struggles are connected with the anarchy theme stated earlier. These women do whatever they want no matter what the consequences will be and when pushed to the logical conclusion they can be very courageous as individuals and heroines. We see other recurring character go through their own smaller struggles at least once and those struggles wouldn't be as impactful if their development was in tandem with the story. What I'm trying to say is static personalities are just as good if they fit the story your trying to tell, and they fit for what this show is trying to do. Two bad ass angels breaking the rules and doing whatever they want. 


Visually, the show is just as chaotic as the ideology the sisters represent. Along with the hard-line 2D visual style popular in many 90's cartoon network shows you'll get visual styles ripped straight from from other well known properties (South Park and Transformers for example), a realistic style, a chibi style, a fan service empathizing style, CGI, you understand my point. And this show is so energetic that multiple styles may be used during a episode. At times, it feels like all these shifts wouldn't make a cohesive package but the crazy part is that they fit with the thematic core; 'Rules are made to be broken.' Art style can shift if it fits the artistic vision. If this was a average anime I'm unsure it would fit but this isn't an average anime. 


The music, man this music... I'd unironically recommend this music to friends; The music is that catchy. I want to dance every time I hear my favorite tracks. But the stipulation I put with this great music is that even the calmer tracks (Chocolat and Beverly Hills Cock Part 2 for example) are energetic and if you expect this show to have moments of peace to level out the excitement you will be disappointed. This show is not calm period.  


Final Thoughts: To say this show is polarizing is an understatement. And the reason (I think) that is, is because  some people have certain exceptions when viewing anime and this show will break those expectations. I think if view this show with the mindset of anarchy you'll come to appreciate it even if you don't think its a masterpiece.

Panty and Stocking wins the award for most unique anime I have ever seen. It takes on animation rivaling that of the Powerpuff Girls, it has mad cool techno beats, it is outrageously perverse, even more so than South Park or Family guy, and its script style feels more like a cartoon than an anime. However, just because its so unique, doesn't mean I thought it was wondrous. 
My first complaint is that the humor isn't really all that funny. Directed towards teens most likely, the jokes of Panty and Stocking boil down to poop jokes, sex jokes, fat jokes, and other such jokes. Myselfbeing a teenager who laughs at such jokes all the time, I strangely didn't find the humor in Panty and Stocking to be that funny. I believe the reason is that there's no subtlety in the jokes. They're all blunt and in your face. While cryptic sex jokes from other franchises can make me crack up laughing, most of the sex jokes in this anime just left me wide jawed thinking "wow". However, thats not to say none of the humor in this anime is funny. I thought many things were funny, like the Objection! lawyer monkey, the reference to Transformers, and the episodic explosion of a real life clay sculpture of the monsters killed in the anime. There's lots of good humor in this anime, its just coupled with blatant out there jokes.


My second problem is the characters. I love character development in my anime, particularly of the backstories of characters. I especially love it when these backstories reveal beautifully why certain characters behave the way they do. There is no such thing in Panty and Stocking. Panty is a slut who thirsts for sex for some unknown reason. Stocking has a love of sweets and has a thing for smelly, fat old men for some unknown reason. These two are chosen to destroy the monsters and whatnot for some unknown reason. Considering how shallow the plot already is, it amazes me how little is actually explained. 


Finally, the final thing I dislike about this anime is its episodic plot. Panty and Stocking feels more like a cartoon because every episode's plot ends inside that episode. In other words I could easily watch only a fraction of the total episodes and not have a problem. The opposite of this is strictly linear anime which has a core plot that is divided unto the episodes of the anime. The latter option generally gives deeper plot in anime and more desire to want to watch the next episode. With Panty and Stocking, upon finishing an episode, I rarely had very much desire to watch the next episode, and that partially is because the plot in the episode I just watched was over already. 


These complaints really don't matter, however, because that's not the kind of anime Panty and Stocking is. P&S is an experiment, completely out of the norm for anime. It does what it likes how it wants to and that is perfectly fine. I enjoyed watching P&S. I didn't get the same kind of entertainment that I usually expect from anime, but instead got something completely out of my comfort box. I am looking forward to the second season; I just wish they wouldn't be so out there with their obscene jokes.

Umm, I'm not sure what to say about this series. It's downright hilarious and downright messed up, too. I have the feeling that this was something America threw out after it was rejected and Japan inherited it. It's got that kind of terrible American animation feel to it (no offense).
But I cannot say that this is entirely retarded (again, no offense). Watching these 13 episodes made me realize something that I have not thought about: Is this really how I waste my time? I mean, seriously now. 24 minutes times 13 episodes makes a total of 5 hours and 12 minutes more or less. Withthat time one can probably do something constructive at least. If not, then maybe something that is educational or emotionally intriguing. This is, for lack of a better word, pointless. If not pointless, then this is just fuel to the stereotyping of the Japanese anime. But I'm not writing this for stereotyping awareness or something like that. I am just pointing out that simply this series made me question procrastination. And I am thankful for that.\n\n
But overall, I don't want to watch anymore of this style of anime; it's simply mindless orgies of insanity.

Think angels are all 'goody-goody'? You're wrong. Meet Panty and Stocking, two angels sent down to our world in this odd anime.
Panty and Stocking with Garterbelt may seem like the stupidest thing you will ever watch in your life, but it's actually truly brilliant with it's story. Why? Because it's not meant to please you. It basically says, 'here's what it is, and if you don't like it, get lost.'
The art, however, seems lacking. Granted I haven't seen a style like this used in an anime, but the art seems like scribbles I draw on my notes in Chemistry class. It's really nothing special inmy eyes.


Sound would be a better rating, but do to the over amount of cussing, there were numerous bleeps and bloops to censor it. I don't have a problem with cussing, but I hate so many bleeps to cover it up and can't hear most of the sentence.


The characters are not really special either, to be honest. The girls were slutty, and it ruined it. I think that the problem is that there really was no unique-ness now that you think about it.


To be honest, I didn't enjoy this show. Even though it's brilliant with it's 'it is what it is', it's really not worth the time.

Oh this show. It's shit. But it still isn't the worst anime I have watched.
The bad. I didn't like the animation style, but seeing as this comes from a company that made series like Kill la Kill and Gurren Laugen, I was extremely disappointed with it. There are a few scenes, the tranformation scenes that you rarely see, were nice, but that doesn't make up for the very minimal effort put into this animation. Their excuse may be a low animation budget, but Kill la Kill, Neon Genesis Evangelion and Gurren Laugen all had low animation budgets, and they are all up there for me.If you read any of my other reviews you'll know that a lot of fan service in a series does bring down the series for me, now if I only find these characters attractive. Fan service can work quite well, look at Queen's Blade it's got enough story that you can look past the nudity and fan service, but Panty and Stocking is a villain of the episode thing without much of a story. A bit of originality on the name part as well. Naming a group of your main characters after undergarments (looking at you DBZ). Another sore part are the jokes, the first few times you get a sexual joke it's kind of funny, but throughout the series it gets less and less funny and pretty much every other joke falls flat on it's face. So what I didn't like was the animation, the lack of story, the overuse of fan service, and unoriginal character naming, oh and unoriginal characters, forgot to mention that. The characters just felt so uninspired and it made me not care as much for them. I generally didn't give a shit about what happened to them at all.


The good. The soundtrack is actually pretty good, as usual with studio Trigger. But I can't think about anything else.


Final Verdict:

Avoid this series if you can. Watch it only so you can argue why it is bad and that's really all. It's uninspired and poorly animated.
